G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u202f19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223 because the events giving rise to these claims occurred within the Commonwealth and within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223 because the events giving rise to these claims occurred within the Commonwealth and within the judicial district of this Court.

G.L. c.\u202f148, \u00a7\u00a7\u202f26E.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and landlord, had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain all smoke detectors in the common areas, including hallways, pursuant to G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E and 26F, and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, 527 C.M.R. 1.00.

527\u202fC.M.R. 1.00.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and landlord, had a statutory and common-law duty to maintain all smoke detectors in the common areas, including hallways, pursuant to G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E and 26F, and the Massachusetts State Fire Code, 527 C.M.R. 1.00.

Jupin v. Kask, 447\u202fMass.\u202f141,\.proposition: To establish negligence under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff must show that (1) the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care; (2) the defendant breached that duty; (3) the plaintiff suffered damages; and (4) the defendant’s breach was the proximate cause of those damages. *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363\u202fMass.\u202f6.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to maintain the Premises and its common areas, including smoke detection equipment, in reasonably safe condition. *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973).

G.L. c.\u202f186, \u00a7\u202f15.proposition: Defendant also had statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, § 15; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E–26F; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.482(B), which requires landlords to maintain operable smoke detectors in multifamily dwellings.

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f148, \u00a7\u00a7\u202.proposition: Defendant also had statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, § 15; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E–26F; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.482(B), which requires landlords to maintain operable smoke detectors in multifamily dwellings.

105\u202fC.M.R.\u202f410.482(B).proposition: Defendant also had statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, § 15; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E–26F; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.482(B), which requires landlords to maintain operable smoke detectors in multifamily dwellings.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Defendant also had statutory duties under G.L. c. 186, § 15; G.L. c. 148, §§ 26E–26F; and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.482(B), which requires landlords to maintain operable smoke detectors in multifamily dwellings. Violation of such statutes constitutes evidence of negligence. *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990).

Young v. Garwacki, 380\u202fMass.\u202f1.proposition: In the landlord‑tenant context, the landlord is liable in negligence for injuries caused by failure to remedy dangerous conditions in common areas under the landlord’s control. *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165 (1980).

Glidden v. Maglio, 430\u202fMass.\u202f6.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constituted a foreseeable and unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff and other tenants. *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).

Souza v. Prario, 456\u202fMass.\u202f472.proposition: Plaintiff was a person lawfully on the premises to whom this duty was owed. *Souza v. Prario*, 456 Mass. 472, 476 (2010).

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s breach was a proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, as the lack of an operating smoke detector delayed her awareness of the fire, resulting in harmful smoke exposure. *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).

Jalbert v. Lafayette Ins. Co., 464\u202f.raw_text: Jalbert v. Lafayette Ins. Co., 464 Mass. 43, 49 (2013)
Jalbert v. Lafayette Ins. Co., 464\u202f.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that disabling or failing to maintain smoke alarms creates a substantial risk of serious injury or death from fire. *Jalbert v. Lafayette Ins. Co.*, 464 Mass. 43, 49 (2013).

Luoni v. Berube, 431\u202fMass.\u202f729.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were a direct and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s negligence. *Restatement (Second) of Torts* § 284; see also *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 732 (2000).

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f84, \u00a7\u202f18.proposition: Plaintiff has complied with or is exempt from any applicable notice requirements under Massachusetts law. *G.L. c. 84, § 18* (by analogy).

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f231, \u00a7\u202f6B.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f93A.proposition: Award statutory attorney’s fees if applicable under G.L. c. 93A (to the extent any unfair act is found);
